lg:flex lg:px-0"><section id="incArticle" class="post-content w-full space-y-4 lg:w-2/3 font-b text-3"><p>The struggles never seem to end for Tesla.</p><p>Elon Musk's embattled electric vehicle empire is floundering on its long-anticipated <a href="https://futurism.com/the-byte/tesla-robotaxi-launch-mess" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">robotaxi launch</a> as <a href="https://futurism.com/tesla-massive-payday-elon-musk" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">sales plummet to record lows</a> and <a href="https://futurism.com/the-byte/longtime-tesla-investor-dumps-stock" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">Tesla bulls dump their stocks</a>.</p><p>Tesla's Cybertruck — the garish luxury all-electric truck — is no exception to the carnage. With a reputation for <a href="https://futurism.com/the-byte/cybertruck-breaks-down-one-mile-driving" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">breaking down constantly</a> and <a href="https://futurism.com/rent-cybertruck-flipped-off" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">drawing the ridicule</a> of just about every other driver on the road, the stainless steel tanks aren't exactly a popular choice for car buyers.</p><p>Earlier this month, news emerged that Tesla was sitting on over <a href="https://futurism.com/tesla-unsold-cybertrucks-crisis" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">10,000 unsold Cybertrucks</a>, an estimated $800 million worth of inventory.</p><p>Now, Tesla has decided to <a href="https://futurism.com/tesla-refusing-cybertrucks-trade-ins" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">start taking Cybertruck trade-ins</a> after over a year of deliveries, and disgruntled customers are already revealing what Tesla is willing to pay for a used rig.</p><p>Though an AWD foundation series Cybertruck will set you back $100,000, Tesla's only willing to pay $65,400 to take it off your hands — and that's presumably if it has 6,000 miles or less on it, <a href="https://electrek.co/2025/05/18/tesla-starts-accepting-cybertruck-trade-ins-confirms-insane-depreciation/" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">according to <em>Electrek</em></a>.</p><p>A screenshot of the trade-in estimate was obtained from a <a href="https://www.cybertruckownersclub.com/forum/threads/cybertruck-trade-ins-are-now-live.42355/" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">disgruntled poster</a> in the Cybertruck Owners Club, noting that it gives the Cybertruck a depreciation rate of about 34.6 percent in just one year.</p><p>A typical pickup truck, claims <em>Electrek</em>, should take three to four years to lose that kind of value.</p><p>It's not exactly shocking news. The cracks had started to show as early as spring of 2024 — just months after Cybertrucks hit the market — as news of the EV's <a href="https://www.fastcompany.com/91129195/the-cybertrucks-aftermarket-price-is-cratering-as-its-flaws-become-too-big-to-ignore" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">shoddy production quality</a> became well-known. Back then, Tesla didn't accept returns, while resellers were understandably reluctant to get involved, sending the <a href="https://electrek.co/2025/04/01/tesla-is-sitting-on-200-million-worth-of-cybertruck-inventory/" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">aftermarket price</a> of a new Cybertruck into the toilet.</p><p>Of course, this is all in stark contrast to Musk's absurd claim that Tesla vehicles would only increase in value, a promise he made back in 2019.</p><p>"If you buy a Tesla today, I believe you are buying an appreciating asset, not a depreciating asset," he said in an <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2024/03/03/cars/musk-tesla-cars-value-ev-prices/index.html" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">interview</a>.</p><p>The Cybertruck isn't the only floundering Tesla product. By last year, a 2021 Tesla Model 3 — which retailed for about $40,000 — was reselling for just $23,700, a 29 percent markdown compared to its price in 2023. The used-car average over the same period was just 19.5 percent, <a href="https://www.dailymail.co.uk/yourmoney/article-13155671/elon-musk-used-tesla-value-price-drop.html" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">according to Edmons.com</a>, a used car site.</p><p>Tesla is also facing fallout from a bizarre leasing program <a href="https://www.reuters.com/sustainability/boards-policy-regulation/musk-took-leased-cars-back-so-tesla-could-use-them-robotaxis-instead-tesla-sold-2025-05-15/" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">revealed by <em>Reuters</em></a> last week. Typically, customers will have an option to buy a car outright at the end of their lease. Instead, Tesla's internal policy made potential buyers send their cars back to Tesla, to be part of Musk's "robotaxi" network.</p><p>Of course, that <a href="https://futurism.com/tesla-struggling-robotaxi-service" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue">robotaxi network</a> has yet to actually materialize. In reality, those cars were being outfitted with the latest software updates and flipped to new buyers for much more than they would have sold to those wrapping up a lease.</p><p>Basically, the writing's on the wall: don't count on a new Tesla's value to go anywhere but down.</p><p class=""><strong>More on Tesla: </strong><a href="https://futurism.com/doomsday-preppers-cybertruck-apocalypse" class="underline hover:text-futurism hover:no-underline transition-all duration-200 ease-in-out" style="text-decoration-color:blue"><em>Doomsday Preppers Say the Cybertruck Is a Horrible Choice for the End of the World</em></a></p><br/><div class="tracking-[.05em] text-center uppercase font-hn  text-futurism text-2 py-4"><p>Share This Article</p><div class="flex items-center justify-center pt-3 rapidly.\"","vertical":"FUTURISM"}]}},"content":"\u003cp\u003eThe struggles never seem to end for Tesla.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eElon Musk's embattled electric vehicle empire is floundering on its long-anticipated \u003ca href=\"https://futurism.com/the-byte/tesla-robotaxi-launch-mess\"\u003erobotaxi launch\u003c/a\u003e as \u003ca href=\"https://futurism.com/tesla-massive-payday-elon-musk\"\u003esales plummet to record lows\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"https://futurism.com/the-byte/longtime-tesla-investor-dumps-stock\"\u003eTesla bulls dump their stocks\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTesla's Cybertruck — the garish luxury all-electric truck — is no exception to the carnage. With a reputation for \u003ca href=\"https://futurism.com/the-byte/cybertruck-breaks-down-one-mile-driving\"\u003ebreaking down constantly\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"https://futurism.com/rent-cybertruck-flipped-off\"\u003edrawing the ridicule\u003c/a\u003e of just about every other driver on the road, the stainless steel tanks aren't exactly a popular choice for car buyers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEarlier this month, news emerged that Tesla was sitting on over \u003ca href=\"https://futurism.com/tesla-unsold-cybertrucks-crisis\"\u003e10,000 unsold Cybertrucks\u003c/a\u003e, an estimated $800 million worth of inventory.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNow, Tesla has decided to \u003ca href=\"https://futurism.com/tesla-refusing-cybertrucks-trade-ins\"\u003estart taking Cybertruck trade-ins\u003c/a\u003e after over a year of deliveries, and disgruntled customers are already revealing what Tesla is willing to pay for a used rig.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThough an AWD foundation series Cybertruck will set you back $100,000, Tesla's only willing to pay $65,400 to take it off your hands — and that's presumably if it has 6,000 miles or less on it, \u003ca href=\"https://electrek.co/2025/05/18/tesla-starts-accepting-cybertruck-trade-ins-confirms-insane-depreciation/\"\u003eaccording to \u003cem\u003eElectrek\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA screenshot of the trade-in estimate was obtained from a \u003ca href=\"https://www.cybertruckownersclub.com/forum/threads/cybertruck-trade-ins-are-now-live.42355/\"\u003edisgruntled poster\u003c/a\u003e in the Cybertruck Owners Club, noting that it gives the Cybertruck a depreciation rate of about 34.6 percent in just one year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA typical pickup truck, claims \u003cem\u003eElectrek\u003c/em\u003e, should take three to four years to lose that kind of value.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt's not exactly shocking news. The cracks had started to show as early as spring of 2024 — just months after Cybertrucks hit the market — as news of the EV's \u003ca href=\"https://www.fastcompany.com/91129195/the-cybertrucks-aftermarket-price-is-cratering-as-its-flaws-become-too-big-to-ignore\"\u003eshoddy production quality\u003c/a\u003e became well-known. Back then, Tesla didn't accept returns, while resellers were understandably reluctant to get involved, sending the \u003ca href=\"https://electrek.co/2025/04/01/tesla-is-sitting-on-200-million-worth-of-cybertruck-inventory/\"\u003eaftermarket price\u003c/a\u003e of a new Cybertruck into the toilet.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOf course, this is all in stark contrast to Musk's absurd claim that Tesla vehicles would only increase in value, a promise he made back in 2019.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\"If you buy a Tesla today, I believe you are buying an appreciating asset, not a depreciating asset,\" he said in an \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2024/03/03/cars/musk-tesla-cars-value-ev-prices/index.html\"\u003einterview\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Cybertruck isn't the only floundering Tesla product. By last year, a 2021 Tesla Model 3 — which retailed for about $40,000 — was reselling for just $23,700, a 29 percent markdown compared to its price in 2023. The used-car average over the same period was just 19.5 percent, \u003ca href=\"https://www.dailymail.co.uk/yourmoney/article-13155671/elon-musk-used-tesla-value-price-drop.html\"\u003eaccording to Edmons.com\u003c/a\u003e, a used car site.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTesla is also facing fallout from a bizarre leasing program \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/sustainability/boards-policy-regulation/musk-took-leased-cars-back-so-tesla-could-use-them-robotaxis-instead-tesla-sold-2025-05-15/\"\u003erevealed by \u003cem\u003eReuters\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e last week. Typically, customers will have an option to buy a car outright at the end of their lease. Instead, Tesla's internal policy made potential buyers send their cars back to Tesla, to be part of Musk's \"robotaxi\" network.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOf course, that \u003ca href=\"https://futurism.com/tesla-struggling-robotaxi-service\"\u003erobotaxi network\u003c/a\u003e has yet to actually materialize. In reality, those cars were being outfitted with the latest software updates and flipped to new buyers for much more than they would have sold to those wrapping up a lease.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBasically, the writing's on the wall: don't count on a new Tesla's value to go anywhere but down.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMore on Tesla: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://futurism.com/doomsday-preppers-cybertruck-apocalypse\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eDoomsday Preppers Say the Cybertruck Is a Horrible Choice for the End of the By last year, a 2021 Tesla Model 3 — which retailed for about $40,000 — was reselling for just $23,700, a 29 percent markdown compared to its price in 2023. The used-car average over the same period was just 19.5 percent, \u003ca href=\"https://www.dailymail.co.uk/yourmoney/article-13155671/elon-musk-used-tesla-value-price-drop.html\"\u003eaccording to Edmons.com\u003c/a\u003e, a used car site.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTesla is also facing fallout from a bizarre leasing program \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/sustainability/boards-policy-regulation/musk-took-leased-cars-back-so-tesla-could-use-them-robotaxis-instead-tesla-sold-2025-05-15/\"\u003erevealed by \u003cem\u003eReuters\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e last week. Typically, customers will have an option to buy a car outright at the end of their lease. Instead, Tesla's internal policy made potential buyers send their cars back to Tesla, to be part of Musk's \"robotaxi\" network.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOf course, that \u003ca href=\"https://futurism.com/tesla-struggling-robotaxi-service\"\u003erobotaxi network\u003c/a\u003e has yet to actually materialize. lease.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBasically, the writing's on the wall: don't count on a new Tesla's value to go anywhere but down.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMore on Tesla: text:
Rewritten: The struggles never seem to end for Tesla.

Elon Musk's embattled electric vehicle empire is floundering on its long-anticipated robotaxi launch as sales plummet to record lows and Tesla bulls dump their stocks.

Tesla's Cybertruck — the garish luxury all-electric truck — is no exception to the carnage. With a reputation for breaking down constantly and drawing the ridicule of just about every other driver on the road, the stainless steel tanks aren't exactly a popular choice for car buyers.

Earlier this month, news emerged that Tesla was sitting on over 10,000 unsold Cybertrucks, an estimated $800 million worth of inventory.

Now, Tesla has decided to start taking Cybertruck trade-ins after over a year of deliveries, and disgruntled customers are already revealing what Tesla is willing to pay for a used rig.

Though an AWD foundation series Cybertruck will set you back $100,000, Tesla's only willing to pay $65,400 to take it off your hands — and that's presumably if it has 6,000 miles or less on it, according to Electrek.

A screenshot of the trade-in estimate was obtained from a disgruntled poster in the Cybertruck Owners Club, noting that it gives the Cybertruck a depreciation rate of about 34.6 percent in just one year.

A typical pickup truck, claims Electrek, should take three to four years to lose that kind of value.
